'''The Norman peasants' revolt''' in 996 was a revolt<ref name="Wiley"/> against [[Normans|Norman]] conquerors. The revolt was defeated by nobility under early reign and minority of [[Richard II, Duke of Normandy]]. His uncle [[Rodulf of Ivry]] was the regent of [[Normandy]] during the revolt.<ref name="Bradbury2004"/><ref name="Burke">http://chesterrep.openrepository.com/cdr/bitstream/10034/322668/6/matthew+paul+burke.pdf</ref>
==Overview==
The revolt was started in 996 after the peasants had met in local assemblies (''conventicula'') of throughout Normandy. The revolt was coordinated by a central assembly (''conventus'') that was formed by members of the local assemblies. Each ''conventicula'' sent two representatives to the central assembly.<ref name="TeBrake1993">{{cite book|author=William H. TeBrake|title=A Plague of Insurrection: Popular Politics and Peasant Revolt in Flanders, 1323-1328|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KSVsjwH6iN0C&pg=PA60|date=1 September 1993|publisher=University of Pennsylvania Press|isbn=0-8122-1526-5|page=60}}</ref>
The peasants wanted concessions on various economic grievances.<ref name="Wiley"/> These included Barons harassing the peasants with vexatious services, the main reason however was the removal of hunting rights, lest a deer be killed.<ref name="Duncan1839">{{cite book |last=Duncan |first=Jonathan |title=The Dukes of Normandy from the time of King Rollo to the expulsion of King John |publisher=Joseph Rickerby and Harvey & Darton |date=1839}}</ref>{{rp|51}} Medieval sources claim that the revolt was caused by demands of free hunting and fishing rights.<ref name="edocs">https://edocs.uis.edu/Departments/LIS/Course_Pages/LIS411/readings/Hilton_Peasant_Society_pp67-94.pdf</ref>
The revolt probably did affect only [[Seine valley]] rather than whole Normandy. Dating of the revolt in 996 has been also disputed.<ref name="Wiley">{{cite journal|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/emed.12010/abstract|title=996 and all that: the Norman peasants' revolt reconsidered|first=Bernard|last=Gowers|date=1 February 2013|publisher=|journal=Early Medieval Europe|volume=21|issue=1|pages=71–98|accessdate=21 June 2016|via=Wiley Online Library|doi=10.1111/emed.12010}}</ref>
==Serfdom==
The revolt may have been a reaction to rise of serfdom in Normandy.<ref name="Faith1999">{{cite book|author=Rosamond Faith|title=The English Peasantry and the Growth of Lordship|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eyHUAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA253|date=1 April 1999|publisher=A&C Black|isbn=978-0-7185-0204-1|pages=252–253}}</ref><ref name="edocs"/> It has been suggested that the revolt resulted in abolishing serfdom in Normandy.{{cn|date=June 2016}} Lack of serfdom in Normandy has been also linked to depopulation of coastal France brought by warfare. However, evidence for existence and extent of serfdom has been difficult to obtain.<ref name="Houts2000">{{cite book|author=Elizabeth Van Houts|title=The Normans in Europe|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IarkHmOdjnsC&pg=PA63|date=15 December 2000|publisher=Manchester University Press|isbn=978-0-7190-4751-0|pages=63–64}}</ref>
==Aftermath==
Peasant leaders who brought complaints to the regent Rodulf of Ivry had their hands and feet cut off, after they were captured.<ref name="Bradbury2004"/><ref name="Burke"/> Others were blinded, impaled, or burnt alive, land owners forfeited their land.<ref name=Duncan1839/>{{rp|51}}
Despite the revolt at start of his reign, rest of the Richard II's reign was very peaceful. In May 1023 he did not implement the [[Peace of God]] due to calm situation in his lands.<ref name="Burke"/> However, Normandian culture returned to its [[French culture|Frankish]] characteristics and lost Scandinavian influences such as [[Old Norman|Norman language]].<ref name="Bradbury2004">{{cite book|author=Jim Bradbury|title=The Routledge Companion to Medieval Warfare|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3FRsBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA144|date=2 August 2004|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-134-59847-2|pages=77–78, 144}}</ref><ref name="Burke"/>
